newsitem.title: GERMANY: Germany's nursing insurance was profitable in 95.
newsitem.headline: Germany's nursing insurance was profitable in 95.

text.p: Germany's private health insurers made gross profits of 240 million marks on the newly introduced private nursing care insurance last year, their association PKV- Verband said.
According to PKV-Verband's general manager Hans-Christoph Uleer, some 200 million marks will be used as reserves for future premium reductions, while 40 million marks are due to the insurers.
Germany's eight million insured with private cover paid 2.56 million marks in premiums for nursing care insurance.
"Our calculations regarding prices and benefits worked out well," said Uleer.
Claims and reserves amounted to 610 million marks, the initial investment into the system ran to 360 million marks.
Some 1.06 billion marks was allocated to old-age reserves. Administrative costs totalled 15 million marks.
Uleer said that so far 71,000 insured had claimed benefits for home care and another 34,000 for stationary care in a nursing home.
Of the claims, the doctors evaluating cases on behalf of insurers turned down around 15 percent in the home care segment and 10 percent in the stationary segment.
